title: Screw LASIK
body: <p>Time for <a href="http://www.wired.com/news/medtech/0,1286,64803,00.html" title="wtf does STAAR stand for anyway?">STAAR</a>!  Here's a summary: </p><blockquote>"A permanent, implantable contact lens that can dramatically improve vision in patients with severe nearsightedness is expected to receive FDA approval by the end of this year. [...] The lens was designed to remain in the eye permanently, but if a patients vision changes, the lens can either be removed and changed, or the patient can get regular corrective glasses, contact lenses or LASIK surgery. [...]The procedure is expected to cost up to 20 percent more than LASIK surgery, which runs about $1,000 per eye [in the US &#8212; it's much cheaper in Canada]."</blockquote><p>I can't wait to tell Lenscrafters to suck it.  I guess <a href="http://www.staar.com/" title="you'd think that they would put what STAAR stands for somewhere on their site">STAAR</a> has some competition as well.  <a href="http://www.amo-inc.com/site/" title="Advanced Medical Optics">AMO</a> has some Verisyse technology which is similar.  The differences being Verisyse has been around since the '70's, it's been performed on over 100,000 people, requires a larger incision, and takes about twice as long (15 minutes vs. 8 minutes).</p>
